"Imam Bukhari’s Advice to His Student: Knowledge is Better than Entertainment and Business

Muhammad ibn al-Abbas al-Firabri said:

One day, Imam al-Bukhari narrated to me a great number of hadiths, and he feared that I might become bored [or tired], so he said: ‘Be happy [and content], for those who spend their time on entertainment are busy with them, those skilled in crafts are busy with their work, and businessmen with their trade, while you are with the Prophet (sallallahu alayhi wa sallam) and his Companions.”

So I said: There is none of these, may Allah have mercy on you, except that I see myself in a better state.

(Siyar A‘lam al-Nubala 12/445)"

It is said: “الصراخ على قدر الألم” — a phrase suggesting that the intensity of a scream corresponds to the level of pain experienced.

After years of producing PDFs that delved into the realms of scholars and rulers—encroaching on their rights, stirring negativity against them, and diminishing their standing in the eyes of the public—followed by strange cycles of repentance followed by retraction from them, and targeting students one after another, the affair then reaching its peak with a disgraceful public attack on al-‘Allāmah al-Bukhārī, حفظه الله تعالى….when rebuttal finally arrived, regrettably, uncontrollable cries are heard…

I advise all intelligent Salafīs to remain focused on their studies and to benefit from our scholars—those who have spent years, even decades, dedicated to teaching through thousands of audios, lectures, books, writings, and khutbas, by the blessing of Allāh. Among them are the likes of al-‘Allāmah al-Bukhārī and Shaikh ‘Arafāt, may Allāh preserve them.

On the other hand, one should consider it troubling that there are those who only become known and raised by others in times of fitnah—without prior recognition for their contributions in the field of knowledge itself.

Discerning great scholars the likes of al-‘Allāmah Rabī & al-‘Allāmah ‘Ubayd رحمهما الله knew exactly who to recommend and put forward—the likes of al-‘Allāmah al-Bukhārī & Shaikh ‘Arafāt among others. They saw what is clear and evident; that they are people who are focused on knowledge and its teaching, and have been for years, even decades, known and recognised for that—something that no-one in the West ever denied, until the grievances of one man opened up chaos and a terrible trajectory for gullible and naive youngsters. 

May Allāh guide our brother Abū ‘Iyād so that he may return from his new disastrous path, 30 years of involvement in da’wah to be wasted like this is a great shame; but it has happened to others before, those far far greater in standing and status than him, we hope it will not end the same for him.

There is no need for him to mention anyone by name. For whoever attacks the firmly grounded scholars is among those who have boarded the ship of the people of innovation and misguidance. And whoever attacks our S͟hayk͟h, Al-ʿAllāmah ʿAbdullāh Al-Buk͟hārī, is weak in intellect and sick in soul.

As for this lost and sick individual whom you mentioned in your question, his attacks against the scholars and the rulers have been established as he claimed that the Arab states “emerged from the desert”!

In reality, states are led only by those in authority, and those in authority are the scholars and the rulers, as stated by the Salaf, including Ibn ʿAbbās (may Allāh be pleased with him).

So, is mentioning the word “desert” a form of praise for the scholars and the rulers, or is it a form of disparagement? We leave the answer to the people of intellect.

Or does he mean by “Arab states” the walls, the buildings, and lifeless things? Or does he mean the bakers and the shop owners?

{Inform me with knowledge if you are truthful.} (Sūrah Al-An ʿām: 6:143)

And the strange thing is that he claimed the Arab states have gone to imitate the West!! As if this strange creature lives inside the Kaʿbah.

We have condemned him by what he uttered with his own tongue; through his speech, he discarded the fatwas of the scholars regarding contemporary issues, following the methodology of Safar Al-Ḥawālī and Salmān Al- ʿAwdah. Then he repented, but later he broke his repentance!

It is enough of a disgrace and a shame for him that he plays with repentance like a wandering sheep between two flocks; and this is among the traits of the people of hypocrisy! For the believer is simple hearted and noble, while the hypocrite is deceitful and wicked.

The Questioner: May Allāh reward you with goodness, our S͟hayk͟h, for your advice. Do you permit me to publish it for the brothers?

The S͟hayk͟h: As you wish.

The Questioner: May Allāh reward you with goodness, our S͟hayk͟h.
